title: How to Make a Monster High House

steps.headline: Find an old Barbie house with three or more rooms.
steps.description: If you don't have one, look in thrift stores or ask your parents to check out a site like Freecycle, where they can put a "wanted" post on. Or, simply use a suitably sized grocery box. Glue in cardboard floors to make different levels. Or, use shoe boxes stacked up next to each other to create dividers inside a larger cardboard box. Glue it all in place so that nothing can wobble and fall out.

steps.headline: Put decorations of your choice along the wall.
steps.description: You might even like to repaint the house in colors you like or that you think suits the dolls. Ask your parents for help in choosing the right paints for the material that your house is made from. And always paint somewhere that has plenty of air flow and where the work surface is well covered.

steps.headline: Put furniture and accessories of your choice in it.
steps.description: You can either buy suitable furniture or make your own (see below for a bed example). Use cardboard boxes, containers, washed bottles, etc. to recycle into doll's furniture.

steps.headline: Find a suitable box.
steps.description: A shoe box is an ideal size, as long as it is large, such as at least size 13 for one doll.

steps.headline: Make a mattress.
steps.description: Measure the box shape. Use this measurement to cut out 2 pieces of fabric slightly smaller than the box shape. Stitch three sides of these two pieces together but leave open one end. Stuff the fabric with quilt wadding or similar stuffing. Stitch the last edge up and you have a mattress for the bed.

steps.headline: Make sheets.
steps.description: Grab any 2 sheets of fabric. Cut them down to fit the bed. Tuck one piece of fabric over the mattress. Use the other piece as the top sheet.

steps.headline: Cut out a piece of felt, old wool fabric or similar for a blanket or duvet.
steps.description: Rest this on top of the bed. It's a good idea to hem this piece to prevent fraying. If you don't know how, ask for help with this.

steps.headline: Make a pillow.
steps.description: Do the same as for making the mattress, only make the two pieces of fabric a lot smaller, pillow size for the box. Stuff and stitch up, then add to the bed.

steps.headline: Make a sleeping mask or a little doll journal as an accessory.

text: Making the House Find an old Barbie house with three or more rooms. If you don't have one, look in thrift stores or ask your parents to check out a site like Freecycle, where they can put a "wanted" post on. Or, simply use a suitably sized grocery box. Glue in cardboard floors to make different levels. Or, use shoe boxes stacked up next to each other to create dividers inside a larger cardboard box. Glue it all in place so that nothing can wobble and fall out. Put decorations of your choice along the wall. You might even like to repaint the house in colors you like or that you think suits the dolls. Ask your parents for help in choosing the right paints for the material that your house is made from. And always paint somewhere that has plenty of air flow and where the work surface is well covered. Put furniture and accessories of your choice in it. You can either buy suitable furniture or make your own (see below for a bed example). Use cardboard boxes, containers, washed bottles, etc. to recycle into doll's furniture. Making a Bed Find a suitable box. A shoe box is an ideal size, as long as it is large, such as at least size 13 for one doll. Make a mattress. Measure the box shape. Use this measurement to cut out 2 pieces of fabric slightly smaller than the box shape. Stitch three sides of these two pieces together but leave open one end. Stuff the fabric with quilt wadding or similar stuffing. Stitch the last edge up and you have a mattress for the bed. Make sheets. Grab any 2 sheets of fabric. Cut them down to fit the bed. Tuck one piece of fabric over the mattress. Use the other piece as the top sheet. Cut out a piece of felt, old wool fabric or similar for a blanket or duvet. Rest this on top of the bed. It's a good idea to hem this piece to prevent fraying. If you don't know how, ask for help with this. Make a pillow. Do the same as for making the mattress, only make the two pieces of fabric a lot smaller, pillow size for the box. Stuff and stitch up, then add to the bed. Make a sleeping mask or a little doll journal as an accessory.
